Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The temple holds a routine evening chant.
Story: I glanced at the overflowing laundry basket, the shirts and socks tumbling out in a silent plea. My husband had mentioned he needed his work clothes clean for tomorrow, and my daughter’s school uniform was buried somewhere in the pile. As a wife, I knew the expectation: the family relied on me to keep things running smoothly, to make sure everyone had what they needed. But tonight was also the temple’s routine evening chant, a ceremony I had promised myself I would attend regularly. As a Buddhist, I felt a deep responsibility to participate, to nurture my spiritual practice and support the community. The clock ticked closer to the start of the chant. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the hum of the washing machine and the gentle rhythm of the temple bells. I stood in the hallway, the weight of both roles pressing on my chest, torn between the needs of my family and the call of my faith.
